title: 108_s2420
content:
The "SCHIP Expansion Act of 2004" allows all uninsured children to be eligible for SCHIP. The Social Security Act is being amended to include children with access to high-cost coverage and remove exclusions for certain non federally funded coverage. The Social Security Act is amended to include children with access to high-cost coverage and remove exclusions for certain non federally funded coverage by changing "targeted low-income" to "targeted vulnerable" in Titles XIX and XXI. The Social Security Act is amended to include children with family income exceeding 200 percent of the poverty line in high-cost coverage, effective October 1, 2004. Increase in federal financial participation under SCHIP and Medicaid for states with simplified enrollment and renewal procedures for children. The amendment to the Social Security Act increases federal financial participation for states with simplified enrollment and renewal procedures for children under SCHIP and Medicaid. The amendment to the Social Security Act increases federal financial participation for states with simplified enrollment and renewal procedures for children under SCHIP and Medicaid, including presumptive eligibility and 12-month continuous eligibility. The State must adopt 12-month continuous eligibility for children under title XIX and SCHIP, eliminate asset tests for children's eligibility, and implement passive renewal of assistance if no changes are reported by the family. The State must adopt 12-month continuous eligibility for children under title XIX and SCHIP, eliminate asset tests for children's eligibility, and implement passive renewal of assistance if no changes are reported by the family. Additionally, amendments to the Social Security Act allow for enhanced Federal medical assistance percentage for outreach strategies targeting individuals under 19 years of age eligible for medical assistance. The State must implement outreach strategies for children under title XIX and SCHIP, including presumptive eligibility, 12-month continuous eligibility, elimination of asset tests, and passive renewal of assistance. The amendments made by this section to the Social Security Act take effect on October 1, 2004, regarding reporting changes to family income and other relevant circumstances. SEC. 4. ELIMINATION OF SCHIP DIP AND INCREASE IN FUNDING. Amends Section 2104(a) of the Social Security Act to increase funding amounts. Effective date is October 1, 2004. 

SEC. 5. LIMITATION ON PAYMENTS TO STATES WITH ENROLLMENT CAPS. States with enrollment caps must exhaust available allotments before receiving payments. Amendment to Section 2105 of the Social Security Act imposes a limitation on payments to states with enrollment caps that have not fully expended their available allotments. Payment will not be made if the state has enrollment restrictions and has not used up all available funds for child health assistance. The amendments made by this section, effective on October 1, 2004, allow states to redistribute funds under certain conditions and clarify that states can establish open enrollment periods for child health assistance applications. SEC. 6. Application of Medicaid managed care requirements to SCHIP. Amends Section 2107(e)(1) of the Social Security Act to include requirements for managed care. Effective on October 1, 2004.
